title: Ticket #5163: Buffer received messages from ReliSock
description:
Currently, there's no buffering on the ReliSock for receiving data (unlike sending data, which is buffered until 4KB or EOM). Each thing coded on the socket (string, integer) is a separate call to recv() (and two fcntl and a poll).

This is especially obvious when receiving ClassAd updates (NOTE: during later investigation, it was revealed that the problematic case is qmgmt updates, not ClassAds). Each attribute in an ad requires two recv()'s, meaning each attribute is about 10 syscalls.

I think RcvMsg should do a non-blocking read into a buffer; if there's insufficient bytes immediately available, then repeat the blocking read with precisely the number of bytes required.
remarks:
2015-Jul-22 22:03:14 by bbockelm:
Chatting with Jaime, there might be something more subtle here (we think that it does "the right thing" in many cases). Maybe this only occurs when in non-blocking mode?

2015-Aug-03 08:55:39 by bbockelm:
Found some time to poke around at this one -

ClassAds didn't seem to be the problem in the end. Instead, it was a lot of the QMGMT commands (for example, condor_submit results in two recvfrom() syscalls per attribute; condor_shadow updates have a similar cost).

Enabling buffering in the ReliSock isn't too tricky - will push a branch soon. The tricky part is the interplay between ReliSock and the Selector object; as the file descriptor no longer has bytes to read, it is no longer marked as ready by select. Hence, any code touching ReliSock's must explicitly understand the buffered mode.

Accordingly, I left buffering off by default and only enabled it for DaemonCore-managed sockets and places where the socket has a short managed lifetime. This will prevent such buffered sockets from leaking to places like the python bindings.
check_ins: 2015-Aug-03 08:42   Check-in [45451]: Allow ReliSock to buffer incoming data. #5163 This adds a buffered mode to the ReliSock (off by default) which keeps a 4KB buffer internal to the socket object itself. As the buffer mode will screw up polling of the underlying FD, it is only enabled for sockets registered for read in DC. (By Brian Bockelman )
